{"title":"Page 40","subjec":{},"descri":{},"creato":{},"publis":{},"date":{},"year":{},"format":{},"reposi":{},"collec":{},"reposa":{},"rights":{},"digitb":{},"langua":{},"topics":{},"cite":{},"notes":{},"notesa":{},"source":{},"box":{},"folder":{},"identi":{},"relati":{},"findin":{},"catalo":{},"type":{},"full":"Dr. Gill informs us that the Countd'Orsay was equally beloved
by Lady Blessington and her husband; the latter making an
extra provision of fortune to either of his daughters that should
marry him. His children were weak and imbecile and had no
sympathy whatever with the step mother or the Count; consequently a separation took place between the latter and his wife, by
mutual consent. Lady Blessing-ion was much annoyed by the
caprice and jealous whims of her step-daughter, and then seems
sequently she took no part in the quarrel between the parties of
her own household, and against one whom she and her husband
so loved and delighted to honor.
He had ever boon her intimate friend, and there was no necessity for her to turn him away. He had been a member of her
household for years, and why should she discard him and place
an unknown in the dubious path of friendship.
